Title: TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROJECT HISTORY AND ANALYSIS REPORT

Abstract: Evaluates the performance of a proj contractor, Robt R Nathan Associates, Inc (RRN), from 3/64 to 9/64.  Proj was intended to strengthen the capability of several Govt of Afghanistan ministries (particularly the Min of Planning-MOP) for designing & executing developmental projects. The performance of RRN appeared highly satisfactory.  Contractor's local team established good working relations with GOA personnel; this team displayed high professional competence and, with good backstopping from its US headquarters, was able to meet its contractual commitments fully and promptly.  GOA's satisfaction with RRN is displayed by its reliance upon RRN assistance for an appraisal of current inflationary pressures, an analysis of current budgetary deficits, and an examination of the feasibility of select projects. Services (or achievements) provided by RRN during this eval period include:  1) directly assisting the MOP with the preparation of projects, eg, the enlarged rural credit program; 2) advising the Min of Agr on its revised research program and on special programs to increase wheat production, develop a dairy processing plant in Kabul, and implement an agr sample census; 3) assisting with efforts to improve the work of assembling, processing & publishing economic statistics; 4) preparing a proposal for the review of the GOA's second Five-Year Plan and presenting this proposal to the MOP; 5) assisting select GOA personnel with the development of curricula in econ planning and providing these personnel with on-the-job training; 6) conducting relevant participant training programs.
Descriptors_Topical: WHEAT|Agricultural policy|Agricultural planning|Economic policy|Economic planning|Participants|Dairies|Institution building|Agricultural production|Agricultural credit|Agricultural research|Limited data
Title: EVALUATION OF CONTRAC'S PERFORMANCE, ROBERT R NATHAN ASSOCIATES

Abstract: This report describes the methods used by A.I.D. in the worldwide participant training evaluation survey.  It also presents selected findings demonstrating the value of this type of evaluation process. (Author abstract)
Title: Evaluation of the technical training program in the United States foreign aid

Abstract: This report, one of 23 country studies conducted as part of a worldwide survey, reviews A.I.D.'s participant training program in Chile from 1943 to 1960.  The report was based on oral interviews with 429 of 1,234 returned participants and 199 supervisors and contains recommendations in the areas of training design, pre-departure, and English language training.  (Author abstract, modified)
Title: Participant training program in Chile : an evaluation survey, 1943-1960

Abstract: This report, one of 23 country studies conducted as part of a worldwide evaluation survey, reviews A.I.D.'s participant training program in Bolivia. The study was based on interviews of 701 of 1,422 returnees, 170 supervisors, and 19 U.S. technicians. Included are recommendations in the areas of training design, third- and in-country training, pre-departure preparation, English language, orientation, follow-up, and professional development. (Author abstract, modified)
Title: Participant training program in Bolivia : final report of a training evaluation study

Abstract: This report is one of twenty-three country studies conducted as part of the worldwide survey of returned participants in accordance with AID/W instructions and guidelines contained in ICATO Circular A-175, November 1959. The major purpose of this global effort was to obtain an overview of how the participant training program was progressing to ascertain ways in which future training might be effective at the country, AID/W, and training institution levels. The study included interviews with 402 returned participants along with 163 supervisors and U.S. technicians. This is a good report with solid recommendations in nearly all the major areas of participant training. (Participant training abstract)
